headline: Washington plays guessing game over New York Times op-ed
subHeadline: 'Senior official' pens anonymous op-ed blasting President Trump; reaction and analysis from the 'Special Report' All-Stars.

utterances.speaker: VICE PRESIDENT MIKE PENCE
utterances.sentences: Anyone who would write an anonymous editorial smearing this president who has provided extraordinary leadership to this country, should not be working for this administration. They ought to do the honorable thing and they ought to resign.

utterances.speaker: SPEAKER OF THE HOUSE PAUL RYAN, R-WIS.
utterances.sentences: If you not interested in helping the president, you shouldn't work for the president as far as I'm concerned.

utterances.speaker: HOUSE MINORITY LEADER NANCY PELOSI, D-CALIF.
utterances.sentences: It probably won't take long for us to find out who wrote it, who has denied it already. I guess by a process of elimination we'll come down to the butler who probably has the most knowledge of the president in the White House. But it is a sad statement.

utterances.speaker: BRET BAIER, ANCHOR
utterances.sentences: It is the latest parlor game apparently in Washington, trying to figure out who wrote this anonymous op-ed in The New York Times criticizing the president, saying that they are working on the inside to prevent any bad things from happening. As a 5:30 p.m. this afternoon, 32 administration officials including the vice president put out official denials. We are told that they have been taking to the president to show him who has put out denials.  Did anyone ever really think it was the Federal Trade Commission chairman? Who knows? But we do know that the first lady put out a statement specifically saying, quote, "People with no names are writing our nation's history. Words are important and accusations can lead to severe consequences. If a person is bold enough to accuse people of negative actions, they have a responsibility to publicly stand by their words. And people have the right to be able to defend themselves. To the writer of the op-ed, you are not protecting this country. You are sabotaging it with your cowardly actions." With that, let's bring back our panel. Mollie?

utterances.speaker: MOLLIE HEMINGWAY, THE FEDERALIST
utterances.sentences: This is really an interesting story and there have been a lot of people trying to figure out who is behind it. But at some level it doesn't really matter who wrote it, in part because it might be some midlevel official, but also because it just confirms that there is a never Trump movement within the administration to actively thwart the will of the electorate. When you are engaging in resistance against a president, that means you are engaging in resistance against the people who elected him.   And this is actually a threat to our constitutional republic. This is not how we do things. We believe in political accountability. And admitting on the pages of The New York Times that you have no transparency, no accountability, and you are working to thwart the will of the electorate is something that is the type of norm-breaking that I think a lot of American people don't like.

utterances.speaker: BAIER
utterances.sentences: We have never seen anything like this. Every day -- we say that a lot, we have never seen anything like this. But really, we have never seen anything like this. And if you think about all the reactions, liberal, conservative, there's a lot of why isn't this person out, resigning, or standing up and being public?

utterances.speaker: SUSAN PAGE, USA TODAY
utterances.sentences: We've never been in a situation where you wake up in the morning and the vice president feels obliged to put out a written statement that he was not the person who wrote the anonymous op-ed piece in The New York Times.

utterances.speaker: BAIER
utterances.sentences: And the first lady.

utterances.speaker: PAGE
utterances.sentences: And apparently not Melania. But there is a constitutional crisis, but there are actually two. There is one that goes to your point, Mollie, that unelected officials are not supposed to undermine the decisions made by a duly elected president. But there is also a second constitutional crisis which is the fitness of the president. Which constitutional crisis you see from this op-ed piece depends on where you stand.

utterances.speaker: BAIER
utterances.sentences: Speaking of that, the deep state is a thing talked about all the time. You've heard a lot about it and it's mentioned. Take a listen.

utterances.speaker: JAMES COMEY, FORMER FBI DIRECTOR
utterances.sentences: I hear this term "deep state" all the time. There is no deep state. But there is a deep culture and a commitment to the rule of law.

utterances.speaker: SENATE MINORITY LEADER CHUCK SCHUMER, D-N.Y.
utterances.sentences: From deep state leaks to unmasking requests, the president and his allies don't quit with all these conspiracy theories, with all these ridiculous fomentations.

utterances.speaker: PRESIDENT DONALD TRUMP
utterances.sentences: I was never a deep state guy. Let me tell you, we have got some bad people that are doing bad things.

utterances.speaker: BAIER
utterances.sentences: I mean, from the president's point of view, he was right.

utterances.speaker: MATTHEW CONTINETTI, WASHINGTON FREE BEACON
utterances.sentences: Right, who are you going to believe, Jim Comey or The New York Times? I do want to speak in defense of the White House butler, though, Bret --

utterances.speaker: CONTINETTI
utterances.sentences: Nancy Pelosi just randomly accusing. I know the butlers on the staff, the White House professional staff are better than this.

utterances.speaker: BAIER
utterances.sentences: I don't think that qualifies as senior administration.

utterances.speaker: CONTINETTI
utterances.sentences: You never know. There is such resume inflation in Washington, D.C., as an editor, and as you know as an anchor, everyone who starts talking to the press on background suddenly becomes a senior administration official. And there are dozens of agencies that this author could work from. I think Mollie is right, there is a problem here with unaccountability. I also think there's a problem, as a subscriber to The New York Times, there is a problem for the institute of The New York Times which is that they've put themselves in the weird position, what happens when this identity leaks and we discover who it is?

utterances.speaker: BAIER
utterances.sentences: How about this, I asked John this earlier: New York Times reporters at the White House, are they trying to peg who this is?

utterances.speaker: CONTINETTI
utterances.sentences: That's the second point. The paper's own reporters in position of trying to uncover the identity of the source and the subjects are their own colleagues.

utterances.speaker: HEMINGWAY
utterances.sentences: But more than that, it was just a huge strategic blunder of people in the media and people in the resistance to think that this would go over well. You do not have to like Donald Trump to like our constitutional system of governance, and I think it is absolutely time for people to stop enabling and supporting this resistance and thinking about who they are resisting against.

utterances.speaker: BAIER
utterances.sentences: Or stand up and say there is a problem and we have to act or something.

utterances.speaker: PAGE
utterances.sentences: The fact is the betrayal of a dysfunctional government, of a toxic workplace, of an erotic president is something that is completely consistent with the Woodward book and with the daily coverage we have seen from the past year and a half from the White House. So in a way what the op-ed author is saying is not surprising.  Content and Programming Copyright 2018 Fox News Network, LLC. ALL RIGHTS RESERVED. Copyright 2018 CQ-Roll Call, Inc.
